titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Leonid Rzhevsky Papers
titlestmt.author: by Lisa Conathan

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday January 22, 2019 at 06:16

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract:
The Leonid Rzhevsky Papers consist of correspondence, writings, clippings and personal papers that document the work of Russian-born novelist and literary critic Leonid Rzhevsky. The papers span the years 1941-1987, with the bulk of the material dating from the 1950s and 1960s. The papers include material related to a few of Rzhevsky's works of fiction but chiefly document his critical essays, lectures and editorial work.
Correspondence and writings document Rzhevsky's role in the twentieth-century Russian emigre literary community in Europe and the United States. Rzhevsky was critical of the Soviet government and advocated for a unified emigre voice to propel Russian literary analysis into the post-Soviet era. Correspondence provides personal insights that are crucial to contextualizing Rzhevsky's creative writing, since his style of fiction approaches that of a memoir when addressing the fate of Soviet refugees (especially in post-War Germany).

langmaterial.language: Materials in Russian, English, German and Swedish.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Leonid Rzhevsky on general Slavic funds in 1983 and from Agnes Rzhevsky on the Edwin J. Beinecke Book Fund in 1989.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
Boxes 20-21: Restricted fragile material. Reference surrogates have been substituted in the main files. For further information consult the appropriate curator.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Leonid Rzhevsky Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Leonid Rzhevsky Papers. Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Partially processed in 1998. Processing completed and finding aid revised in 2008.

The Library of Congress system is used to transliterate Russian language, but diacritics are not used. Illustrative examples are: Iuz Aleshkovskii and Efim Etkind. Names of Russian emigres are spelled in accordance with the individual's usage or record of publication. Therefore these spellings do not necessarily conform to standard Library of Congress transliteration. For example, the spelling Rzhevsky is used throughout the finding aid (instead of Rzhevskii).

bioghist.head: Leonid Denisovich Rzhevsky (1905-1986)
bioghist.p: Leonid Denisovich Rzhevsky was born with the family name Surazhevskii on August 21, 1905 in Moscow. He graduated from Moscow Second University in 1930 and completed his graduate training at the Lenin Pedagogical Institute in 1941 with the rank of Kandidat. In 1953 he emigrated from the Soviet Union, teaching for several years at the University of Lund in Sweden before moving permanently to the United States in 1963. He taught on the faculty of the University of Oklahoma, Norman (1963-1964), New York University (1964-1974) and the Norwich University Russian School summer program (1968-1980s).

Rzhevsky published numerous novels, stories, and critical essays beginning in the 1950s. He was active in the anti-communist Russian emigre community and had long-standing associations with the journals Posev (and the affiliated publishing house) and Grani . Rzhevsky also edited radio broadcasts on literary and political topics for Radio Liberty (in Russian: Radio Osvobozhdenie) in the 1950s.

Rzhevsky's major works of fiction include the novels Mezhdu dvukh zvezd (1953), Pokazavshemu nam svet (1960), Dve strochki vremeni (1976), Dina (1979), and Bunt podsolnechnika (1981) and the short story collections Dvoe na kamne (1963) and Cherez proliv (1966). His major works of criticism include Iazyk i totalitarizm (1951 and 1953), Prochten'e tvorcheskogo slova (1970), Tvorets i podvig (1972), Tri temy po Dostoevskomu (1972) and numerous shorter essays. Many of his essays were pseudonymous under the name L. Tann, which was derived from a family name in Rzhevsky's maternal lineage (Von der Tann).
Rzhevsky's wife was Agniia (Agnes) Sergeevna Shishkova. They married in 1943.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Leonid Rzhevsky Papers consist of correspondence, writings, clippings and personal papers that document the work of Russian-born novelist and literary critic Leonid Rzhevsky. The papers span the years 1941-1987, with the bulk of the material dating from the 1950s and 1960s. The papers include material related to a few of Rzhevsky's works of fiction but chiefly document his critical essays, lectures and editorial work.

Correspondence and writings document Rzhevsky's role in the twentieth-century Russian emigre literary community in Europe and the United States. Rzhevsky was critical of the Soviet government and advocated for a unified emigre voice to propel Russian literary analysis into the post-Soviet era. Correspondence provides personal insights that are crucial to contextualizing Rzhevsky's creative writing, since his style of fiction approaches that of a memoir when addressing the fate of Soviet refugees (especially in post-War Germany).

Rzhevsky's editorial work is documented in his correspondence with "second wave" emigre literary figures, many of whom fled to Europe and the United States via Germany in the wake of the Second World War. Much of the correspondence is addressed to Rzhevsky both in a personal capacity and in his capacity as editor of Grani from 1952 to 1955 and of Novyi Zhurnal from 1975 to 1976. Correspondents such as Igor Chinnov, Ivan Elagin and Boris Filippov proposed essays for publication and discussed writings of Rzhevsky and others. In many cases, correspondence that began on formal editorial terms continued after Rzhevsky's tenure as editor.

The papers include dozens of drafts and printed versions of Rzhevsky's essays and lectures. His writings and lectures address diverse topics in Russian literature, including stylistics in the work of Solzhenitsyn, spiritual themes in the work of Dostoevsky, and innovations in the language of contemporary Soviet poets.

The papers also include fragmentary documentation of Rzhevsky's teaching, including correspondence with students and the schedules of symposia he organized at Norwich University in the 1970s and 1980s.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three series: I. Correspondence, 1948-1987. II. Writings and Lectures, 1941-1985. III. Other Papers, 1961-1986.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically. Unidentified correspondence is filed at the end of the alphabetical listing.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence documents Rzhevsky's role as editor and writer of literary fiction and criticism within the Russian emigre communities in Europe and the United States. A large part of the correspondence, especially that in the 1950s, relates to Rzhevsky's editorial work for the journal Grani . Later correspondence also relates to conferences and lectures that Rzhevsky organized or attended and includes letters from students. Many letters, while not primarily personal, include details about the daily lives of Russian emigres in Germany, France, Sweden and the United States.
Most correspondence is incoming but some files also include drafts or copies of outgoing letters. Some correspondence is addressed to Agnes Rzhevsky.
Correspondence related to the publication and translation of Tvorets i Podvig ( Creator and Heroic Deed ) is also filed in Series II, Writings and Lectures.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes poetry by Nadezhda Teffi.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes a statement (1951) to the International Refugee Organization about Leonid and Agnes Rzhevsky.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series II is organized into five subseries: Longer Works, Essays and Other Shorter Works, Lectures, Radio Scripts, and Writings of Others. Untitled and unidentified works are filed at the end of the alphabetical listing in each subseries. Newspaper clippings of printed essays are filed at the end of the Essays and Other Shorter Works subseries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Writings and Lectures consist of drafts and printed versions of essays, lectures, and radio scripts, and material relating to a few longer works (a playscript, Rzhevsky's dissertation and an edited volume of the correspondence of Kornei Chukovskii). The material chiefly documents Rzhevsky's literary analysis and there is little representation of Rzhevsky's many works of fiction.

The subjects of Rzhevsky's literary analysis are diverse within the scope of Russian-language literature, ranging from Aleksandr Pushkin to Bella Akhmadulina. In his essays and lectures, Rzhevsky employed stylistic and lexical analysis to discuss creativity and the relationship of literature to society. He also addressed the importance of emigration in defining twentieth-century Russian-language literature.
Some essays are written under the pseudonym L. Tann.
Writings of Others consists of drafts of two essays in German by Maria de Smeth.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A collection of essays by various authors (including Rzhevsky) on stylistics.

did.physloc: Also stored in: Oversize box 19 folder 411

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A planned publication of the correspondence between Kornei Chukovskii (a Russian children's poet) and Sonia Gordon of New York City. The material consists of transcripts and photocopies of letters that date from 1964 to1967, annotated by Rzhevsky. Topics of the correspondence include Vladimir Nabokov, Nikolai Nekrasov, the exchange of books, and Chukovskii's health and personal life.

did.unittitle: Untitled Russian-language reader for second-year college study, draft

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Drafts and individual offprints are arranged alphabetically. Newspaper clippings of printed essays are arranged chronologically at the end of the subseries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Drafts (most are typescripts; a few are holograph) unless otherwise indicated.

scopecontent.p: Includes autobiographical notes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Consist chiefly of critical essays printed in serial publications. Most clippings were published in Posev (1948-1953) and Novoe Russkoe Slovo (1967-1985) though there are also clippings from Deutsch-russische Stossrichtung (1953), Russkaia Mysl' (1957), and Literaturnyi Kur'er (1980s).

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: For an English translation, see "Pilate's sin: cryptography in Bulgakov's novel, The Master and Margarita"

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged by type of material. Clippings about Rzhevsky are arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Other Papers include clippings about Rzhevsky, programs from conferences that he attended or organized, and receipts and other financial records. Conference programs include comprehensive lists of participants in symposia that Rzhevsky organized at Norwich University.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Consists of reviews, essays and opinion pieces on Rzhevsky's work, on other authors, and on related topics.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes Rzhevsky's 75th and 80th Jubilee and obituaries of Rzhevsky.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes receipts for books, hotel stays and daily purchases and utility bills.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Consists of dietary recommendations. Does not include medical records.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes newsletters from homeowners' associations.
